feed.title: IMEC Lab
feed.subtitle: At IMEC, we work at the intersection between systems, embedded AI, and data. We develop resource-efficient and real-time systems that can embed intelligent perception, reasoning, and understanding into common infrastructure and everyday objects found all around us and utilize these systems in efficient ways to enable useful services and improve our overall quality of life. Our work spans a number of domains, including mobile and embedded systems, cyber-physical systems, edge computing, signal processing, machine learning, wearables, robotics, health, intelligent built environments, etc.

entry.title: “Anemoi: A Low-cost Sensorless Indoor Drone System for Automatic Mapping of 3D Airflow Fields” Accepted and Presented at MobiCom 2023

link.title: “Anemoi: A Low-cost Sensorless Indoor Drone System for Automatic Mapping of 3D Airflow Fields” Accepted and Presented at MobiCom 2023

entry.content:
“Anemoi: A Low-cost Sensorless Indoor Drone System for Automatic Mapping of 3D Airflow Fields” accepted and presented at the ACM 29th Annual International Conference on Mobile Computing and Networking (MobiCom 2023) in Madrid, Spain. Congrats team!

Anemoi is a sub-$100 drone-based system for autonomously mapping 3D airflow fields in indoor environments. Anemoi leverages the effects of airflow on motor control signals to estimate the magnitude and direction of wind at any given point in space.

entry.title: “A Data-Driven and Human-Centric EV Charging Recommendation System at City-Scale” Accepted and Presented at ACM e-Energy 2023

link.title: “A Data-Driven and Human-Centric EV Charging Recommendation System at City-Scale” Accepted and Presented at ACM e-Energy 2023

entry.content:
“A Data-Driven and Human-Centric EV Charging Recommendation System at City-Scale” was accepted and presented at the 14th ACM International Conference on Future Energy Systems (e-Energy 2023), co-located with FCRC 2023. Congrats team!

In this paper, we present a practical, data-driven, and human-centric EV charging recommendation system at the city-scale based on deep reinforcement learning (DRL). The system co-optimizes the welfare of both the EV drivers and the grid. We augmented and aggregated data from various sources, including public data, location-based data companies, and government authorities, with different formats and time granularities. The data includes EV charger information, grid capacity, EV driving behavior information, and city-scale mobility. We created a 30-day per-minute unified EV charger information dataset with charging prices and grid capacity, as well as an EV driving behavior dataset with location and State of Charge (SoC) information. Our evaluation of the recommendation system shows that it is able to provide recommendations that reduce the average driver-to-charger distance and minimize the number of times chargers switch to a different driver.

We constructed an EV driving-charging-dataset containing 61,392 valid trips in Nov. 2022 and open-sourced the dataset to facilitate the research in this area.

entry.title: LegoSENSE Accepted and Presented at IoTDI 2023

link.title: LegoSENSE Accepted and Presented at IoTDI 2023

entry.content:
“LegoSENSE: An Open and Modular Sensing Platform for Rapidly-Deployable IoT Applications” was accepted and presented at the 8th ACM/IEEE Conference on Internet of Things Design and Implementation (IoTDI 2023), co-located with CPS-IoT Week 2023. Congrats team!

LegoSENSE is a low-cost open-source and modular platform that makes it simple for anyone to rapidly set up and deploy a custmoized sensing solution for application specific IoT deployments through ‘plug and play’ and ‘mix and match’.
